lang.name: en_CA
lang.key: Maintained by Madison Kelly (mkelly@alteeve.ca) for the APC UPS Scan Agent.
APC/Schneider Electronics UPS Scan Agent
The DB table [#!variable!table!#] for the UPS with the serial number: [#!variable!ups_name!#] (named: [#!variable!ups_name!#]) needs to be updated.
Starting to read the SNMP OIDs for the UPS: [#!variable!ups!#].
SNMP OIDs reads for the UPS: [#!variable!ups!#] completed in: [#!variable!time!#].
No change in UPS power state, update of 'power' table not needed for UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#].
The UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has a new host name: - [#!variable!old_value!#] -> [#!variable!new_value!#]
The UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has a new IP address: - [#!variable!old_value!#] -> [#!variable!new_value!#]

The UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has had its start time after input power is restored changed: - [#!variable!old_value!#s] -> [#!variable!new_value!#s] Note: This controls how long the UPS will wait after the input power has returned until it starts providing output power.

The UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has had its shutdown delay time changed: - [#!variable!old_value!#s] -> [#!variable!new_value!#s] Note: This controls how long the UPS will wait after being asked to power down before actually disabling it's output power.

The UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has had its firmware updated: - [#!variable!old_value!#] -> [#!variable!new_value!#] Note: The firmware is software inside the UPS that controls how the UPS operates and how users interact with it. Typically a firmware is upgraded by an administrator to fox bugs or add new functionality.
The UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has had its health status changed: - [#!variable!old_value!#] -> [#!variable!new_value!#]

The UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has had the high-voltage transfer voltage decreased: - [#!variable!old_value!# vAC] -> [#!variable!new_value!# vAC] Note: An administrator may have made this change in order to help protect more sensitive down-stream equipment from high input voltages. This will likely shorten the life of the UPSes as the UPS will switch to batteries earlier on high-input power.

The UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has had the high-voltage transfer voltage increased: - [#!variable!old_value!# vAC] -> [#!variable!new_value!# vAC] Note: An administrator may have made this change in order to reduce how often the UPS switches to batteries. This may be done in cases where input power is often high and the down-stream equipment is known to be able to handle the higher voltage without issue. This change would help extend the life of the batteries.

The UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has had the low-voltage transfer voltage increased: - [#!variable!old_value!# vAC] -> [#!variable!new_value!# vAC] Note: An administrator may have made this change in order to help protect more sensitive down-stream equipment from low input voltages. This will likely shorten the life of the UPSes as the UPS will switch to batteries earlier on low-input power.

The UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has had the low-voltage transfer voltage decreased: - [#!variable!old_value!# vAC] -> [#!variable!new_value!# vAC] Note: An administrator may have made this change in order to reduce how often the UPS switches to batteries. This may be done in cases where input power is often low and the down-stream equipment is known to be able to handle the lower voltage without issue. This change would help extend the life of the batteries.
The UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has a new "last transfer to batteries" reason: - [#!variable!old_value!#] -> [#!variable!new_value!#]

The UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has a new manufactured date: - [#!variable!old_value!#] -> [#!variable!new_value!#] (yyyy/mm/dd) Warning: This really should never happen and might be a symptom of a problem with the #!string!scan_apc_ups_brand_0001!#. As such, it's a warning level alert. Please send this alert to: #!string!scancore_brand_0003!# (#!string!scancore_brand_0004!#) so that it can be investigated.

The UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has a new model number: - [#!variable!old_value!#] -> [#!variable!new_value!#] Warning: This really should never happen and might be a symptom of a problem with the #!string!scan_apc_ups_brand_0001!#. As such, it's a warning level alert. Please send this alert to: #!string!scancore_brand_0003!# (#!string!scancore_brand_0004!#) so that it can be investigated.

The UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] is using a new internal measurement of temperature: - [°#!variable!old_value!#] -> [°#!variable!new_value!#] Note: #!string!scancore_brand_0001!# converts everything internally to #!string!tools_suffix_0011!# (#!string!tools_suffix_0010!#), so this change should have no visible impact.

The UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has had its network interfaces's firmware updated: - [#!variable!old_value!#] -> [#!variable!new_value!#] Note: The firmware is software inside the UPS's network interface card that controls how the card operates and how users interact with it. Typically a firmware is upgraded by an administrator to fox bugs or add new functionality.

The UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has had its network interface's serial number changed: - [#!variable!old_value!#] -> [#!variable!new_value!#] Note: This probably a result of the network card being replaced.

The UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has had its network interface's MAC address changed: - [#!variable!old_value!#] -> [#!variable!new_value!#] Note: This probably a result of the network card being replaced.

The UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has had its battery's estimated replacement date change: - [#!variable!old_value!#] -> [#!variable!new_value!#] (yyyy/mm/dd) Note: If the date has changed significantly, it is probably because an administrator has replaced the batteries. If the change was minor, it probably was caused by a change in how often the UPS has run on it's batteries.

The UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has had its battery fail: - [#!variable!old_value!#] -> [#!variable!new_value!#] Note: The battery will need to be replaced. Please order an APC brand: [#!variable!battery_model!#] battery.

The UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has had its battery replaced: - [#!variable!old_value!#] -> [#!variable!new_value!#] Note: The battery appears to have been replaced with a: [#!variable!battery_model!#] model battery.
The UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has had its battery changed: - [#!variable!old_value!#] -> [#!variable!new_value!#] Note: The battery appears to have been replaced by an administrator.
The UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] is charging: - [#!variable!old_value!#%] -> [#!variable!new_value!#%]
The UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has charged to it's "minimum good" charge percentage: - [#!variable!old_value!#%] -> [#!variable!new_value!#%]
The UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has finished charging: - [#!variable!old_value!#%] -> [#!variable!new_value!#%]
The UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] is discharging!: - [#!variable!old_value!#%] -> [#!variable!new_value!#%]

The UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has discharged below the warning threshold!: - [#!variable!old_value!#%] -> [#!variable!new_value!#%] Warning: If power is not restored soon, this UPS will be marked as unusable. If the other UPS(es) also drop below this level, your #!string!scancore_brand_0002!# will automatically shut down, if configured to do so.

The UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has had its battery's last replacement date changed: - [#!variable!old_value!#] -> [#!variable!new_value!#] (yyyy/mm/dd) Note: This is most likely do to an administrator replacing the battery pack in the UPS.

The UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has had its battery enter a warning state!: - [#!variable!old_value!#] -> [#!variable!new_value!#] Warning: It is possible that the battery has failed and will need to be replaced.

The UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has had its battery recover from a warning state: - [#!variable!old_value!#] -> [#!variable!new_value!#] Note: This is most likely do to an administrator replacing the battery pack in the UPS.
The temperature of the battery in the UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] is rising: - [#!variable!old_value!# °C] -> [#!variable!new_value!# °C]

The temperature of the battery in the UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] is getting close to the critical temperature of: [#!variable!critical_temperature!#] °C!: - [#!variable!old_value!# °C] -> [#!variable!new_value!# °C]
The temperature of the battery in the UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] is falling: - [#!variable!old_value!# °C] -> [#!variable!new_value!# °C]
The temperature of the battery in the UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has fallen back down below safe levels: - [#!variable!old_value!# °C] -> [#!variable!new_value!# °C]

The temperature of the battery in the UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has reached the critical temperature of: [#!variable!critical_temperature!#] °C!: - [#!variable!old_value!# °C] -> [#!variable!new_value!# °C] Warning: The UPS will soon be powered off if the temperature continues to rise.

The temperature of the battery in the UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has reached the shutdown temperature of: [#!variable!shutdown_temperature!#] °C!: - [#!variable!old_value!# °C] -> [#!variable!new_value!# °C] Critical: The UPS will now be powered off.
The temperature of the battery in the UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has fallen below critical levels: - [#!variable!old_value!# °C] -> [#!variable!new_value!# °C]
The UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has had its battery alarm temperature changed: - [#!variable!old_value!# °C] -> [#!variable!new_value!# °C]
The voltage from the battery in the UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has changed: - [#!variable!old_value!# vDC] -> [#!variable!new_value!# vDC]
The input frequency to the UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has changed: - [#!variable!old_value!# Hz] -> [#!variable!new_value!# Hz]
The input sensitivity for the UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has changed: - [#!variable!old_value!#] -> [#!variable!new_value!#]
The input voltage for the UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has risen: - [#!variable!old_value!# vAC] -> [#!variable!new_value!# vAC]
The input voltage for the UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has dropped: - [#!variable!old_value!# vAC] -> [#!variable!new_value!# vAC]
The input voltage for the UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has gone above the high-voltage transfer level!: - [#!variable!old_value!# vAC] -> [#!variable!new_value!# vAC]
The input voltage for the UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has dropped below the low-voltage transfer level!: - [#!variable!old_value!# vAC] -> [#!variable!new_value!# vAC]

The input voltage for the UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has risen back above the low-voltage transfer level and is operating normally again: - [#!variable!old_value!# vAC] -> [#!variable!new_value!# vAC]

The input voltage for the UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has dropped back down below the high-voltage transfer level and is operating normally again: - [#!variable!old_value!# vAC] -> [#!variable!new_value!# vAC]
The highest input voltage seen in the last 60 seconds for the UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has changed: - [#!variable!old_value!# vAC] -> [#!variable!new_value!# vAC]
The lowest input voltage seen in the last 60 seconds for the UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has changed: - [#!variable!old_value!# vAC] -> [#!variable!new_value!# vAC]
The load percentage on the UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has changed: - [#!variable!old_value!#%] -> [#!variable!new_value!#%]
The UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] is now running on batteries: - [#!variable!old_value!#] -> [#!variable!new_value!#]
The UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has returned to running on mains power: - [#!variable!old_value!#] -> [#!variable!new_value!#]
The time on batteries for the UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has changed: - [#!variable!old_value!#] -> [#!variable!new_value!#]

The estimated hold-up time for the UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has changed: - [#!variable!old_value!#] -> [#!variable!new_value!#] Note: This is an estimate of how long the UPS can provide power should the input power be lost at the current load level. An increase in the average load will shorten the actual hold-up time.
The output frequency for the UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has changed: - [#!variable!old_value!# Hz] -> [#!variable!new_value!# Hz]
The output voltage for the UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has changed: - [#!variable!old_value!# vAC] -> [#!variable!new_value!# vAC]
The UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has lost input power!: - [#!variable!old_value!# vAC] -> [#!variable!new_value!# vAC]
The UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has input power again: - [#!variable!old_value!# vAC] -> [#!variable!new_value!# vAC]
The total lifetime power output from the UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has increased: - [#!variable!old_value!# kWh] -> [#!variable!new_value!# kWh]

Connection to the UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has been lost! Warning: The UPS power state and hold up time can no longer be monitored. Graceful shutdown in the case of a power loss may not function until communication is restored!
Connection to the UPS: [#!variable!ups_name!#] has been restored.
The variable: [#!variable!name!#] should have been an integer, but it appears it was not. Read: [#!variable!value!#].
Communication with the UPS has been lost.
The UPS's health is in an unknown state.
The UPS is operating normally.
The UPS is running on it's batteries. It is likely that the input power feeding the UPS has failed.
The UPS is compensating for low input power.
The UPS is in a timed sleep. It will power back on when the timer has expired.

The UPS is in bypass-mode and was placed in this mode by software. Power is passing to downstream devices through a radio frequency interference filter, but is not conditioned in any other way. Batter protection is not available.
The UPS is off. No power is being provided to down-stream equipment.
The UPS is currently rebooting.

The UPS is in bypass-mode and was placed in this mode by a hardware switch. Power is passing to downstream devices through a radio frequency interference filter, but is not conditioned in any other way. Batter protection is not available.

The UPS is in bypass-mode because of an internal failure. Power is passing to downstream devices through a radio frequency interference filter, but is not conditioned in any other way. Batter protection is not available.
The UPS has lost input power and is sleeping. It will restore output power once input power has been restored.
The UPS is compensating for high input voltage.

The UPS is operating in low-power mode. In this mode, the UPS is in static bypass mode and it is drawing very little power. If a fault is detected, it will switch to either normal operation or forced static bypass mode.
The UPS is operating in hot-standby mode.
The UPS is performing a test of it's batteries.

The UPS has been placed in emergency static bypass mode. Power is passing to downstream devices through a radio frequency interference filter, but is not conditioned in any other way. Batter protection is not available.
The UPS is in static bypass standby mode. It is not currently providing power to downstream devices.
The UPS is in power saving mode. The front panel display will be off but the UPS is operating normally.
The UPS is in SPoT (Self Power Test) operating mode.
The UPS is in ECOnversion mode. The UPS is providing power to the downstream devices via the bypass. The UPS's inverter is operational and ready to take over the output load if an input fault occurs.
There is no information on when the UPS last transfered to battery.
The UPS has not transfered to battery power since the last time it booted.
The UPS last transfered to batteries because of high input voltage.
The UPS last transfered to batteries because of a brown out. That is, a prolonged drop in input voltage from the mains circuit.
The UPS last transfered to batteries because of a black out. That is, a prolonged loss of input voltage from the mains circuit.
The UPS last transfered to batteries because of a brief, minor reduction of input voltage from the mains circuit.
The UPS last transfered to batteries because of a brief, significant reduction of input voltage from the mains circuit.
The UPS last transfered to batteries because of a brief, minor increase of input voltage from the mains circuit.
The UPS last transfered to batteries because of a brief, significant spike of input voltage from the mains circuit.
The UPS last transfered to batteries as part of a planned self-test.
The UPS last transfered to batteries because of a significant change of input voltage from the mains circuit.
The UPS battery state was not read.
The UPS battery is in an unknown state.
The UPS battery is operating normally.
The UPS battery is in a low voltage state.
The UPS battery is in a failed state and needs to be replaced.
The UPS battery health is unknown.
The UPS battery is healthy.
The UPS battery has failed and needs to be replaced.
The UPS is an 'Online' (dual-conversion) UPS so input sensitivity is not used.
The UPS is automatically determining the input power sensitivity.

The UPS is set to have a low input sensitivity. It will not switch to batteries unless the input power degrades significantly. This mode should only be used if the downstream equipment can handle a wider range of input voltages and frequencies.
The UPS is set to medium input sensitivity. This will cause the UPS to transfer to battery power under moderately distorted input.

The UPS is set to high sensitivity. It will switch to battery power under minor input distortion, providing the best protection for downstream equipment, but will shorten the servicable life of the batteries if input power distorts frequently.
Starting #!string!scan_apc_ups_brand_0001!#:

-=] APC UPS Scan Agent
DESCRIPTION
This program is a "scan agent" for the ScanCore alert, monitoring and recovery tool for the Anvil! high-availabiltiy platform.
It monitors APC/Schneider brand UPSes. When run on Anvil! nodes, it will gracefully shut down all servers, withdraw the nodes from the cluster stack and power the node down when the UPSes powering the node are running on batteries and the estimated runtime drops below a critical level.
When run on Striker dashboards, it will provide up to date information on the health of APC brand UPSes so that ScanCore can determine when it is safe to restart nodes that have gone into emergency-stop.
SWITCHES
-upses <ups1>[,<ups2>,...,<upsN>]
Specify the UPS(es) to query. If host names are used, they must be convertable to IP addresses. Two or more UPSes can be defined using commas and *no* spaces to separate them.
This is optional. By default, the scan agent will read /etc/hosts and any entries with a host name containing 'ups' will be checked. If you are not using /etc/hosts, then be sure to set:
scancore::agent::scan-apc-ups::switches::ups = <ups1>[,<ups2>,...,<upsN>]
This will tell ScanCore to call this agent using this switch.
-h, -?, --help
Show this dialog and exit.
SUPPORT
https://alteeve.ca/w/Support
Alteeve's Niche!
No APC/Schneider brand UPSes found, exiting.
A new APC/Schneider brand UPS was found!

-=] UPS Information:
- Model: [#!variable!model!#] (may not be exact) - Serial Number: [#!variable!serial_number!#] - Manufactured: [#!variable!manufactured_date!#] (yyyy/mm/dd) - Host Name: [#!variable!name!#] - IP Address: [#!variable!ip!#] - Firmware Version: [#!variable!firmware_version!#]
-=] Network Interface Information:
- Serial Number: [#!variable!nmc_serial_number!#] - Firmware Version: [#!variable!nmc_firmware_version!#] - MAC Address: [#!variable!nmc_mac_address!#]
-=] Battery Information:
- Model Number: [#!variable!battery_model!#] - Current Battery Installed: [#!variable!battery_last_replacement_date!#] (yyyy/mm/dd) - Estimated Replacement Date: [#!variable!battery_replacement_date!#] (yyyy/mm/dd)
-=] UPS Configuration:
- Delay between input power being restored and turning back on: [#!variable!ac_restore_delay!#] second(s). - Delay between shutdown command received and actual shut down: [#!variable!shutdown_delay!#] second(s). - Transfer to batteries when input power goes below: [#!variable!low_transfer_voltage!#] or above: [#!variable!high_transfer_voltage!#] vAC. - #!variable!input_sensitivity!#
-=] Current Sensor Values:
- Battery Temperature: [#!variable!battery_temperature!#]°C (alarms at: [#!variable!battery_alarm_temperature!#]°C) - Battery Voltage: [#!variable!battery_voltage!#] vDC - Input Power Frequency: [#!variable!input_frequency!#] Hz - Input Power Voltage: [#!variable!input_voltage!#] vAC - In the last 60 seconds, the input voltage ranged from: [#!variable!input_1m_minimum_input_voltage!#] to: [#!variable!input_1m_maximum_input_voltage!#] vAC. - Estimated Runtime: [#!variable!say_estimated_runtime!#] - Output Load Percentage: [#!variable!output_load_percentage!#] % - Output Power Frequency: [#!variable!output_frequency!#] Hz - Output Power Voltage: [#!variable!output_voltage!#] vAC - Lifetime Power Output: [#!variable!output_total_output!#] kWh
-=] UPS Health Information:
- #!variable!health!# - #!variable!last_transfer_reason!# - #!variable!battery_health!# - #!variable!battery_state!# - #!variable!say_time_on_batteries!#
The UPS is not running on batteries.
The UPS has been running on batteries for: [#!variable!output_time_on_batteries!#]
A new UPS named: [#!variable!name!#] has been found
